section.title: Requirements
section.para:
The following will be needed on hand.
A 64 gigabyte sd card.
A host computer (i.e. your laptop) with an sd card reader.
A Raspberry Pi (model 2 is preferable but the B is OK)
A microUSB charger >= 2Amp rating.
A USB Wi-fi dongle
Many of the Wi-fi dongles on the market limit the number of clients (often only 5 or 6) making them unsuitable for server use. The canakit.com CanaKit RSP-Pi-WIFI1 is not subject to this limit. (We've tested it and found it to work with up to 26 clients.) The price (11.95) is reasonable but shipping is costly so buying in bulk makes sense.
The CanaKit Pi 2 Starter Kit includes the Pi, a charger and a Wi-fi dongle as well as other things.

section.title: Raspbian
section.para:
Using your personal computer (in this context assumed to be a Debian based Linux system) set up a project directory, and beneath that another directory into which to download the image. From within the latter directory, 'wget' the rapbian image. This can all be accomplished with the following commands.
$ cd $ mkdir Project $ cd Project $ mkdir Images $ cd Images $ wget https://downloads.raspberrypi.org/raspbian_latest
The Raspbian download site provides the SHA-1 (of the form 97888fcd9bfbbae2a359b0f1d199850852bf0104) which can be checked using the following command.
$ sha1 2016-2-26-raspbian-jessie.zip
To unzip the image:
$ unzip 2016-2-26-raspbian-jessie.zip
It is extremely important to know with certainty how your host names your sd card. This can be assertained by running the mount command before and than again after inserting the card into your computer's card reader. After insertion there'll be one (or possibly more) extra line(s) of output, the beginning of which will be of the form dev/sdb1 on ..../. The "/dev/sdb" is the crucial part (without the final integer.) Make a note of it. If it isn't "/dev/sdb", substitute what ever it is for "/dev/sdb" in the following code.
$ sudo dd if=~/Project/Images/2016-2-26-raspbian-jessie.img of=/dev/sdb bs=1M
